Description: CITGO pleaded guilty and was sentenced to pay a $13 million fine for the negligent discharge of pollutants into two rivers in Louisiana in violation of the Clean Water Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: CITGO Petroleum Corporation and CITGO Refining and Chemicals Company LLP were sentenced in U.S. District Court in Corpus Christi for violations of the Clean Air Act related to its illegal operation of two massive tanks at their Corpus Christi East Plant Refinery as oil water separators without the required emission control equipment. The failure to equip the tanks with emission controls exposed numerous residents in the Oak Park and Hillcrest communities to chemical emissions. CITGO Petroleum Corporation was ordered to pay a fine of $500,000 on each of the two Clean Air Act counts of conviction. CITGO Refining and Chemicals Company LLP was ordered to pay a fine of $500,000 on each of the federal Clean Air Act counts of conviction plus $15,000 on each of the three misdemeanor Migratory Bird Treaty Act conviction, for a total of $45,000.

As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, CITGO Petroleum agreed to spend $320 million on new emissions control equipment, pay a $3.6 million civil penalty and spend $5 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The Department of Justice and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced that Houston-based CITGO Petroleum Corp. (CITGO) has agreed to pay a $737,000 civil penalty and to implement projects to reduce harmful air pollution, resolving alleged violations of the Clean Air Act (CAA) at its petroleum refining facilities located in Lemont, Ill., and Lake Charles (Westlake), La.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: CITGO agreed to pay a $3.6 million civil penalty and spend $5 million on environmental projects to resolve a Clean Air Act case brought by Louisiana, Georgia and New Jersey as well as the federal government. This was part of a larger $328 million settlement negotiated by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-citgo-petroleum
Five Madison Heights gas stations and their owners pleaded guilty or no contest to charges of engaging in a gasoline price fixing operation.
Citgo Petroleum agreed to pay $120,000 in settlement of allegations it released 250 to 300 pounds of hydrogen sulfide into the atmosphere at its Lemont facility
The State alleged that a number of CITGO's retail-dealers had been selling unbranded or off-brand gasoline as CITGO motor fuel, in violation of the Motor Fuels Act.

Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: Citgo agreed to pay the state $280,075 and spend $819,925 on environmental projects in settlement of multiple alleged violations of its air and water discharge permits and failures to properly operate treatment and control equipment.
Notes: Penalty includes $819,925 on Beneficial Environmental Projects.

Description: CITGO Petroleum Corporation agreed to pay $19.69 million to resolve federal and state claims for natural resource damages under the Oil Pollution Act and the Louisiana Oil Spill Prevention and Response Act.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: CITGO agreed to pay over $18 million to resolve class action litigation alleging that it sold tractor fluid that was not up to modern specifications and damaged equipment.
Private Litigation Case Title: Hornbeck et al v. Orscheln Farm And Home, LLC et al
